newsitem.title: FRANCE: Market dislikes govt Renault intervention.
newsitem.headline: Market dislikes govt Renault intervention.

text.p: Shares in car maker Renault SA fell on the Paris stock market on Wednesday with dealers citing dislike for the government's apparent intervention in the company's decision to close a plant in Belgium and cut jobs.
At 1156 GMT, the share was down 3.1 percent at 137.50 francs, after having posted big gains on Friday and Monday.
"The market welcomed the Belgian plant closure and the job cuts. But they do not like the recent developments," a Paris broker said.
"It looks like the decision may have to be altered and even (Renault chairman Louis) Schweitzer's position could be in doubt," he said.

Prime Minister Alain Juppe has summoned Schweitzer and the company's general secretary Michel de Virville for talks at 1630 GMT and has asked them to inform him about the method used by the group to announce its plans.
Renault is 46 percent owned by the state after a two-stage privatisation in 1994 and 1996.

Government spokesman Alain Lamassoure said after a weekly cabinet meeting that Juppe had said the method used by Renault "was not the right one". Industry Minister Franck Borotra, defended Renault's restructuring decision in parliament on Tuesday. On Wednesday he said had confidence in Schweitzer.
